Abstract: This study explores the organizational structures and operational strategies of social enterprises, focusing on their unique position at the intersection of the nonprofit and for-profit sectors. By analyzing a diverse range of social enterprises, including nonprofits and public benefit corporations, the research aims to uncover the key factors that contribute to their success in achieving social and environmental objectives while maintaining financial sustainability. The investigation employs a mixed-methods approach, combining qualitative case studies with quantitative data analysis, to provide a comprehensive understanding of how social entrepreneurship drives innovation and social change. The findings highlight the importance of adaptive governance models, stakeholder engagement, and impact measurement in the effective organization of social enterprises. This research contributes to the growing body of knowledge on social entrepreneurship and offers practical insights for practitioners and policymakers aiming to support the development of sustainable social enterprises.
